stem: A 35-year-old male patient complains of hyperpigmented macules on the chest and arms. They become lighter in color under the sunlight. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the appropriate treatment?
disc:
Tinea Versicolor is a common fungal infection, especially in tropical countries. Adolescents and young adults are the more commonly affected. It is noncontagious.

Clinical findings include hypo/hyperpigmented and erythematous macules commonly found in the upper trunk and arms.

A KOH preparation can be used to diagnose TV quickly. An alternative is Wood's lamp examination.

Treatment includes topical azole antifungals, selenium sulfide, and zinc pyrithione. They are effective and well-tolerated in mild to moderate diseases. In adults with extensive disease, an oral azole antifungal (e.g. fluconazole 300mg once weekly for two weeks) is recommended than a topical agent.
